title: Jewish students fear grad disruptions , dont feel safe on campus : poll
message:
Anti-Israel protests on campuses have left a majority of Jewish students feeling less safe at school, with 40% saying they feel they must hide their Jewish identities, a new survey found.
Hillel International, a Jewish campus organization, polled 310 students across the country and found four in 10 admitted to hiding their Jewish identities on campus and 32% have been too afraid to attend religious events.
6 Forty percent of the students polled have felt the need to hide their Jewish identity from others on campus.
James Keivom6 Some Jewish students even reported not wanting to return to campus next fall.
“Jewish students, and all students, deserve to pursue their education and celebrate their graduations free from disruption, antisemitism, and hate,” said Adam Lehman, president and CEO of Hillel.

title: MTA members divided over union injection into debate over Israel - Hamas war
message:
Garcia’s support for the MTA withered with each new action, as she and other Jewish members repeatedly raised concerns about antisemitism.
AdvertisementThe division over the Israel-Hamas war is pitting members against one another in the state’s largest teachers union.
The MTA is far from being alone in contending with differing viewpoints on the Israel-Hamas war among its members.
The MTA first officially waded into the Israel-Hamas war on Nov. 4, when its executive board called for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.
Many Jewish members urged the MTA to scrap the webinar.

title: Guest Opinion : Showing up for those with whom we dont agree
message: State Alabama Alaska Arizona Arkansas California Colorado Connecticut Delaware Florida Georgia Hawaii Idaho Illinois Indiana Iowa Kansas Kentucky Louisiana Maine Maryland Massachusetts Michigan Minnesota Mississippi Missouri Montana Nebraska Nevada New Hampshire New Jersey New Mexico New York North Carolina North Dakota Ohio Oklahoma Oregon Pennsylvania Rhode Island South Carolina South Dakota Tennessee Texas Utah Vermont Virginia Washington Washington D.C. title: Faith leaders urge UCSD to bar Islamophobic speakers from campus
message:
SAN DIEGO (FOX 5/KUSI) — A coalition of faith leaders gathered at UC San Diego on Friday to call on the university’s administration to do better to address Islamophobia on campus after a student organization hosted a controversial speaker known for anti-Muslim rhetoric.
The collective of faith leaders, which included Islamic, Christian and Jewish clergy, described his presence on campus as an exemplar of a larger rise in Islamophobia spurred by the Israel-Hamas war that has made Muslim UCSD students feel unsafe on campus.
“We are here to tell the UCSD Administration, the chancellor, that these speakers are not welcome,” said Taha Hassane, imam of the Islamic Center of San Diego.
Hundreds of campus community members have also begun to call for Khosla’s resignation over his response to the encampment.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to FOX 5 San Diego & KUSI News.

title: Pro - Palestinian demonstrators chant  Intifada revolution  and  UK government watch your back , Palestine is coming back  as Met police move in to make arrest
message:
Pro-Palestinian demonstrators chanted 'Intifada revolution' and 'UK government watch your back, Palestine is coming back' on the streets of London as tensions overspilled over the ongoing conflict in the Middle East.
Protesters assembled at the BBC's London headquarters, planning to walk south via Regent Street and Haymarket before concluding at Downing Street.
The word has acquired connotations through two Palestinian uprisings against Israel, between 1987 and 1993, and between 2000 and 2005.
The group have organised demonstrations to coincide with a number of the large-scale marches set up by pro-Palestinian groups in recent weeks.
'By refusing to stop selling these arms, the UK is complicit in the slaughter of civilians taking place daily in Gaza.'

title: Rudy Rochman , Oct . 7 survivors tell their story to London Jewry
message:
Rudy Rochman, a Jewish rights activist with a large social media following, facilitated a conversation between two October 7 survivors and a group of young professionals in London on Wednesday.
The event, organized by the Jewish Learning Exchange (JLE), was attended by 250 young professionals who heard from husband and wife October 7 survivors, Shaled and Yifrat Porat.
While Shaked fought off the terrorists, Yafet and their three children closed themselves in their home’s shelter.
It is this feeling of togetherness that has kept us going as a nation, and we feel it here tonight in London, too.
Fighting antisemitism on campusRochman also spoke with Sacha Johnstone, JLE Young Professional Consultant, and discussed the mass student protests and “encampments” at Columbia and New York Universities.

title: College Professors Are Being Fired for Activism on Gaza War
message:
That’s because many of the professors most supportive of Palestine don’t have jobs anymore.
From campus to campus, professors have defended students’ right to protest, but when scholars themselves espouse support for Palestine and opposition to the Israeli state, professional consequences have frequently been grave.
By and large, professors facing job loss and suspensions over Palestine have brought these allegations into public view by speaking out themselves.
All of them have been in support of the Palestinian cause.”We are at the dawn of a “new McCarthyism,” Levy said.
In the last months, school administrators called in riot cops to clear student encampments and arrest thousands at Columbia University, City College of New York, Emerson College, Emory University, New York University, the University of Austin at Texas, and more.

title: Arrested . Injured . Suspended . Six NYC university students say theyll keep protesting
message:
/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR After being arrested inside Hamilton Hall, Columbia University graduate student Aidan Parisi got a tattoo — a watermelon slice — symbolizing Palestinian solidarity.
Wong, Juwara, and the other arrested students NPR spoke with all said they were conscious of the potential consequences of defying their universities.
Here are those six students:/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Allie Wong's tattoo is of a sculpture titled "Non-violence" that stands outside New York's United Nations Headquarters.
/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Bashir Juwara said that as a student body president, he felt a responsibility to advocate for his classmates' right to protest.
/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Marie Adele Grosso, 19, a sophomore at Barnard College, was arrested twice.

Wong, Juwara, and the other arrested students NPR spoke with all said they were conscious of the potential consequences of defying their universities.
Here are those six students:/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Allie Wong's tattoo is of a sculpture titled "Non-violence" that stands outside New York's United Nations Headquarters.
/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Bashir Juwara said that as a student body president, he felt a responsibility to advocate for his classmates' right to protest.
/ Keren Carrión/NPR / Keren Carrión/NPR Marie Adele Grosso, 19, a sophomore at Barnard College, was arrested twice.
